contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox VG|title=Abrams Battle Tank |image=[[Image:Abrams Battle Tank box art.jpg|256px|center|Abrams Battle Tank box cover (European)]] |caption=Box Art |developer=[[Dynamix]] |publisher=[[Electronic Arts]], [[Sega]] |distributor= |designer=[[Damon Slye]] |programmer= |artist= |composer= |engine=3D engine also used in ''[[Betrayal at Krondor]]'' |version= |platforms=[[MS-DOS]], [[Mega Drive]] |released={{vgy|1988}} |genre=[[Vehicle simulation game|Vehicle simulation]] |modes=[[Single-player]] |ratings=N/A |input= |media=[[ROM cartridge|Cartridge]] |requirements= |cpu= |sound= |display= |license= |language= }} '''''Abrams Battle Tank''''', aka '''''M-1 Abrams Battle Tank''''' for the [[Sega]] version, is a [[computer game]] developed by [[Dynamix]] and published by [[Electronic Arts]] in 1988 for [[DOS]]. It was later ported to [[Mega Drive]] in 1991 by [[Realtime Games Software]]. Designed by [[Damon Slye]], the game is a 3D [[Vehicle simulation game|vehicle simulation]] of the [[M1 Abrams]] [[tank]], one of the first on the market. [[Image:M-1 Abrams Battle Tank Genesis Screenshot.png|thumb|left|The first level]] The port from DOS to [[Sega Genesis]] was performed by [[Realtime Games|Realtime Games Software Ltd]] in the UK using their own 3D games engine that was earlier used in [[Carrier Command]] with some tweaks to adapt it to the Genesis and the needs of the tank scenario. Although the simulation depicts the four crew positions, and is advertised as a simulation, gameplay is not actually very realistic; the missions are [[arcade game]]-like with a fixed sequence of actions to perform.<ref name="CGW"/> The graphics were very good for their time, but reviews are mixed, with many players enjoying the "fun factor" introduced by the lack of realism, and others decrying it for the same reason. ==Reception== The MS-DOS version of the game was reviewed in 1989 in ''[[Dragon (magazine)|Dragon]]'' #147 by Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk Lesser in "The Role of Computers" column. The reviewers gave the game 3 out of 5 stars.<ref name="Dragon147">{{cite journal |title=The Role of Computers |author=Lesser, Hartley, Patricia, and Kirk |journal=Dragon |issue=147 |date=July 1989 |pages=76–83}}</ref> ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' gave the game a somewhat positive review, noting ''Abrams Battle Tank'' does well as a game but is incredibly lacking as a simulation. In particular, the commanding officer's briefings, at one point threatening failure with execution, were derided as unprofessional and offensive to military personnel.<ref name = "CGW">{{citation | date = June 1989 | last = Brooks | first = M.
